metadata.h1: 5 Steps for Creating Your Own GGplot Theme
metadata.description: How to create your own ggplot theme. Themes control all non-data display and are an easy way to change the appearance of your graph. It only takes one extra line of code in order to do this, and ggplot already comes with 8 separate themes.

all_paragraphs: Ggplot is R’s premier data visualization package. Its popularity can likely be attributed to its ease of use — with just a few lines of code you are able to produce great visualizations. If you’re already familiar with ggplot, you likely have used themes themes already. But if you haven’t used themes yet or are not familiar with them:

Themes control all non-data display and are an easy way to change the appearance of your graph. It only takes one extra line of code in order to do this, and ggplot already comes with 8 separate themes.

Before creating your first ggplot theme, it’s good to ask yourself three things:

2. How familiar am I with R package development? If you want to create a ggplot theme, it will need to live in an R package. This is usually the biggest obstacle for someone when they make their first ggplot theme. If you already have experience developing packages, then you’re in luck — creating your own theme can be as quick as 30 minutes. However, if you haven’t yet worked with packages, you’ll need to first spend some time to read up on the fundamentals of package development, which could take a few hours. If you think that you’ll be using R a lot in your future, this would be a good time to start learning the basics of package development!

3. Who would be using this theme? If you work for a company with a lot of R users, it may be good to push for some consistency in data visualization. If your company doesn’t already have a ggplot theme, this could be a clear win for your analytics org and investing time to make a theme should be considered more heavily. If it’s just you that will use the theme, imagine how impressive your graphs will look after and how much time you would save!

There’s no avoiding this — your ggplot theme will need to live in a package. Whether it’s a package that already exists, or a package that you’ll need to create — you’ll want to find the right home for your theme.

Because package development in itself can fill a series of articles, I won’t get too deep into it for now, but if this is your first time developing a package, I would highly recommend reading through the first six chapters of Hadley’s R package guide.

Once you have your package, you’ll want to create a separate file in the package directory with the same name as your theme. In general, you’ll want to start your theme name with theme_ . For example, theme_bw(), theme_void() .
For some guidance on what this file might look like, you can reference:

This is the most exciting step —you’ll want to start playing around with ggplot theme options here in order to dictate what you want your theme to look like. There are a myriad of parameters, but I would highly recommend reading through the documentation for ggplot::theme .
To get you started, you can always begin with an existing theme. For example, if you like the look of theme_classic() , you can use that theme as a foundation for your own theme:
In terms of discovering your theme aesthetics, you’ll generally want to test your theme out with a few different visualizations:

For this, I would recommend just creating a scratch R file that you can sandbox in and create various graphs in until you start honing in on something that you like. Don’t stress out too much about this step! If you find out down the line that you want to make changes to your theme, that would be really easy to do.

For example, for the default font size, you might want to set the default for a size that is best suited for a word doc. But if you end up creating a ggplot for a graph that will be used for a PowerPoint slide, you would also want the ability to increase the text size.
